content.rendered:
A good estate plan will do more than help our loved ones after we’re gone; it will also give them the tools and guidance they need to care for us if we are ever incapacitated and unable to make decisions for ourselves. Planning for potential incapacity is an important estate planning goal and is accomplished with several key documents:

  • Durable Power of Attorney
  • Health Care Directive
  • HIPAA Authorization

Many Springfields assume that they will automatically be granted the right to make medical, financial, and legal decisions on behalf of their spouses or adult children if they are ever incapacitated and unable to care for themselves. Unfortunately, without incapacity documents in place, your loved ones will face a court process to gain the legal right to care for you.

If you need assistance with incapacity documents and planning, contact our Springfield & Springfield attorney.
